ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I gained knowledge on country music, and it's history. I gained insight of US history looking through the lens of country music.
historical analysis, musical analysis, song analysis, history of country music.
Really extensive understanding of the history of country music but also a more in-depth understanding of "the South"
We took a deep dive into the history of country music within the US.We went from hillbilly music all the way up to current music.
I learned more nuanced ways to think about music and its history, through the scope of geography, important figures, and important songs.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the strength is having the class really small. It helps with the discussion format.
absolutely loved this course.

Dean B fosters a really welcoming and warm environment. Class is really chill and I actually looked forward to classes because we'd laugh a lot during class and just talk about music

I didn't think there were any weaknesses to be honest, besides that it was on Zoom, which wasn't in anyone's control
I don't think there were any weaknesses. This was just an amazing class.
I think a little bit more structure for the final paper could have been nice (maybe a good example that we can all read) but otherwise, the course was great!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We spent a lot of time looking at media (video recordings, listening to music), so remote learning actually worked out in that regard
Dean B made this class very engaging even on days when we were quiet and weren't responding as much.
Honestly, I feel like the class could've functioned the same, but with in person meetings and discussions and it would have been as fun or almost as fun

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If they're really into music, then sure I'd recommend it. If you're not really into music, then this class gets boring.  Your reading musical analysis and stuff like that.
yes! awesome first year seminar
YES!!! I have become such a big fan of country music and I feel so informed not only about the history of country music but also history of the American South
Whether you enjoy country music or not, you will love this class.

I would definitely recommend the course to anyone even remotely interested in Country music. You don't even have to listen to that much country already to enjoy it, just have to be interested in learning about it.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: n/a
N/A
